publicationstmt.publisher: State University of New York at Oswego

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid created with EADitor by Zachary Vickery.
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

did.abstract: Professional collection of Dr. Virginia Radley, the eighth president of SUNY Oswego. Dr. Radley, the first woman president of a state-operated campus in the SUNY system, led the way to bolstering Oswego’s strong commitment to academic quality. She shepherded the establishment of the college’s Honors Program, Quest day of scholarly and creative activity and other endeavors that continue to provide depth and diversity to the Oswego experience.

repository.corpname: State University of New York at Oswego

accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to the public

bioghist.p: Dr. Virginia Radley was the eighth president of SUNY Oswego from 1978 to 1988. She came to Oswego in 1974 as provost and executive vice president. Radley became acting president for two months in 1976 and was inaugurated president on October 7, 1978. Virginia Radley was the first woman president in SUNY. During her term as president she increased the enrollment of minorities at SUNY Oswego and supported affirmative action in recruiting and promoting faculty and staff. Academic excellence was stressed, and she revised a general education program and developed the honors program in Liberal Studies. She also worked for women's rights and better academic advising. Sheldon Hall was placed on the register of historic landmarks during her administration. She resigned in 1988 to teach English.

Dr. Radley was Chairman of the English Department at Russell Sage College, Troy, New York in 1966. She received a B.A. from Russell Sage College, an M.A. from the University of Rochester and an M.S. and Ph.D. from Syracuse University.
She taught at Goucher College and lectured at Syracuse University and Nazareth College.

scopecontent.p: Contains Radley's correspondence starting from 1973 and ending in 1993. Contains newspaper clippings and other published material about Radley from the 1970's to the 1990's. There are copies of her speeches from 1974 to 1975. Contains copies of her published work, information about her inauguration and information about her resignation. Also includes a plaque presented to Dr. Radley.

arrangement.p: Chronologically and by type of record.

scopecontent.p:
The Virginia Radley Papers were largely together and arranged prior to the added work done in 1999. In March 1999, the scattered fragments of Radley's Papers which had been filed elsewhere were gathered together and added to the existing arrangement to make one intact collection. New sources of information by or about Virginia Radley were also interfiled with the already processed Radley papers in the possession of Special Collections. Most of these were from Lynn Ekfelt at St. Lawrence University, but one folder apparently was sent by Dr. Radley to Nancy Osborne in 1994. Some clippings from other collections were also rounded up and added.
The series of appointment books was received by Special Collections' Coordinator Nancy Osborne from Dr. Natalie Woodall.
Addition papers were added in 2006. Papers were gathered from throughout Special Collections, additional newspaper clippings were added and photographs were scanned into this record.

userestrict.p: Please contact SUNY Oswego Archives and Special Collections for use restrictions.

scopecontent.p:
Letters from the office of Dr. Virginia L. Radley. Correspondents include:

Speeches of Dr. Virginia L. Radley including the following:
Involvement of Women in the Governance Process: Decision Making. December 1973. 17 typed pages. Includes 11-page draft with editing notes.
Exceeding One's Grasp: A view of excellence. SUNY Brockport Honors Convocation speech. April 3, 1974. Includes 9-page typed draft with editing notes, Honors Convocation program, and thank you letter from John C. Crandall, Vice President for Instruction and Curriculum, State University College at Brockport. 2 copies of speech.
The Man Faces of Eve: Some SUNY Firsts. Six typed pages. n.d.
Speech given to the open meeting of the Academic Policies Council on September 11, 1975. Six typed pages with editing notes.
"Discipline Versus the 'Viewless Wings of Poesy' " by Virginia L. Radley. Reprint from Liberal Education, Vol. XLIX, No. 4, December 1963. Six pages.
Untitled speech on post-secondary education. n.d. 12 typed pages.
Untitled speech on the historical context within which women have moved, stood still, or fled in and from the groves of academe. n.d. 4 typed pages.
Welcome speech at the opening ceremonies of the 1975 New York State Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women's Volleyball Tournament. 1-page typed speech.
Trends in Adminstration of Higher Education in the 70's. Thirteen page draft with editing notes. 26-page speech with editing notes.
(Formerly 1/9/194)

Speeches of Dr. Virginia L. Radley including the following:

Radley, Executive Vice President/Provost, State University College at Oswego, at a conference entitled, "Road to Survival: Financial Management in a Changing Environment," sponsored by the State Education Department, February 25, 1976. Thirteen typed pages with bibliography. Also includes six pages of handwritten notes. Edited.
Remarks on Expectations for the Administrative Team. June 1977. Includes memorandum, typed with editing notes, and handwritten notes. 10 pages. Two copies of typed memorandum.

Speech to Resident Assistants. August 1977. Seven handwritten pages.
Welcome new students. Third Curriculum. August 30, 1977. Nine handwritten pages.
Speech to freshmen. August 30, 1977. Eight pages of handwritten notes.
Founder's Day Address. Russell Sage College. October 6, 1977. Eight pages. 3 copies.
Informal Evening with Waterbury and Scales Hall at Waterbury. October 11, 1977. 6 handwritten pages.
(Formerly 1/9/194)

Speeches of Dr. Virginia L. Radley including the following:
General Faculty Meeting. February 6, 1985. Seven handwritten pages. Attached is an article from Science, Vol. 227, January 1985, by Constance Holden, "Restoration of the Humanities Urged. NEH chairman decries 'garage sale' look of college curricula; says it's time to get back to the classics".
"The Interior World of the Intellect: Jubilee Celebration at Marymount Manhattan College in New York City". November 24, 1985. Seven typed pages with editing notations signed Dr. Virginia L. Radley.

Chamber of Commerce Breakfast. October 7, 1985. Three handwritten pages. Unsigned.

"Topics for Speech to the Men's Honor Society". September 19, 1985. Seven typed pages. 2 copies. Attached are two letters from Oswego graduates Joanne Cono and Melissa Bettinger. Also included is a copy of a handwritten letter to Governor Cuomo from an Elderhostel participant, Ceil Gordet.

Sheldon Association. July 1985. Five pages of handwritten notes (red ink).

Images & Visions". Also includes "Bridging the Gap: Networking for Women" announcement, agenda and registration form.
(Formerly 1/9/194)

Undated speeches of Dr. Viginia L. Radley including the following:
Fidessa-Duessa: Perceptions of a Woman Administrator in a Male Dominated Institution. Speech delivered by Dr. Virginia L. Radley, Executive Vice President/Provost, State University College of Arts and Sciences, Oswego, New York. 15 typed pages. 2 copies.
7 pages of handwritten notes. n.d. "The next 100 years - "
6 pages of handwritten notes. n.d. "What every woman Ph.D. should know if she aspires to be an administrator".
Middle States Chairs. n.d. 8 handwritten pages.
"Women in management". n.d. 4 pages of handwritten notes.
Wingspread Conference Speech. "The 1980's: Women and Higher Education". 7 typed pages with editing notes. Onionskin.
Presidential statement. The issue of quality. 7 typed pages with editing notes. n.d.
"Upward Mobility for Women". 5 typed pages. n.d. Onionskin.
"Women and the Arts". 4 typed pages with editing notes. n.d.
Also includes notes for untitled and undated speeches.
(Formerly 1/9/194)

Published works of Dr. Virginia L. Radley including the following:
"Discipline Versus the 'Viewless Wings of Poesy' " by Virginia L. Radley. Reprint from Liberal Education, Vol. XLIX, No. 4, December 1963. Pages 1-6. Three reprints. Two photocopies.
"The Humanist Dean and Management Systems". Reprint from Liberal Education, May 1974, Vol. LX, No. 2. Pages 228 - 235. 4 copies (variations and 1 photocopy)
"Involvement of Women in the Governance Process: Decision Making". 2 typed copies. 16 pages. Published by the New York State Education Department. Spring 1974.
"Christabel: Directions Old and New". Studies in English Literature. Volume IV, Number 4, Autumn 1964. Pages 531 - 541.
(Formerly 1/9/194)

Papers relating to Dr. Virginia L. Radley's inauguration as the eighth President of SUNY Oswego. Included are the following:
Correspondence and memorandums, meeting minutes, in regards to the planning and administrative duties for Dr. Radley's inauguration. Correspondents include David Nellis, Dr. Clifton R. Wharton, Jr., Public Ceremonies Committee, Provost Ralph Spencer, Dr. Dorothy Rogers, Patti M. Peterson, Margaret Richardson, Rosemary Nesbitt, David Glick, Lynn Hemink, Michael D. Jones, Steven D. Sucher, Dr. J. Michael Adams, Dr. John Knapp, Henry Angle, Donald Batchelor, Margaret Richardson, Dr. Judy Wellman, and Martin Lindenmayer.
Flyer for the President's Colloquia, October 5 - 7, 1978. Two copies. Colloquium introduction. 3 typed pages. Inauguration agenda. 5 pages.
"Oswego Alumni Association Presents Homecoming Dinner and Presidential Ball, October 7, 1978". Program. Bifold with insert of agenda.
"Alumni and Parents Homecoming Weekend featuring The Installation of Virginia L. Radley Oswego's Eighth President. October 6 - 8, 1978. Trifold program with photographs.
"The Inauguration of Dr. Virginia L. Radley as the eighth President of The State University of New York College of Arts and Sciences at Oswego". Bifold program with Schedule of Events insert. 3 copies.
"The Infinite Kingdom of Mind". Inaugural address of Dr. Virginia L. Radley.
President's Colloquia schedule of events with correspondence from participants - Joseph Weicha, Ronald Brown and Diana Balmori. "The Language of the Discipline".
(Formerly 1/9/92)

Letters, memorandum, publications, remarks and newspaper clippings concerning Dr. Virginia L. Radley's resignation. Correspondents include the following:
Clifton R. Wharton, Jr., Chancellor, State University of New York. Dr. Jerome B. Kosimer, Executive Vice Chancellor, State University of New York. John T. Sullivan, Jr. Office of Public Affairs news release. September 3, 1987. Faculty Meeting remarks by Dr. Radley. September 3, 1987. John Kares Smith, Professor of Communications Studies, SUNY Oswego. Helena Howe, Cayuga County Community College President Emeritus. Muriel Allerton "City Will Be Poorer When Radley Exits". Palladium-Times, September 8, 1987. Sanford Sternlicht Dorothy P. Heindel Elizabeth Ward, Director, Russsell Sage College Alumnae Association. Coy (Ludwig?) Humphrey Tonkin, President, Potsdam College. Howard L. Simmons, Ph.D., Associate Director, Middle States Association. Jeffrey W. Hurrin (Class of '79), SUNY New Paltz. Prentiss Carnell III, President, Albany Business College. Frank Horton, U.S.Congressman, New York. F. H. Ratzeburg, SUNY Oswego professor, Psychology Department. Sylvia Chu, SUNY Oswego. Andrew D. Hopkins, University of Rochester. Dr. Sherron Knopp, Williams College. Susan Donnelly, Registrar, Bunker Hill Community College, Boston, MA. Judith Davidson Moyers, Board of Trustees, State University of New York.
Also included is Dr. Virginia L. Radley's vitae. Bifold. 4 copies.
(Formerly 1/9/217)

2-page typed biography of Dr. Radley. Not cited.
(Formerly 1/9/194)

Correspondence from the office of Dr. Virginia L. Radley. Correspondents include:
Dolores B. Schmidt, Assistant Vice Chancellor for Affirmative Action, SUNY. Dr. Foster S. Brown John J. Castle (Class of 1934)
Grace McCarthy Knitter writes about her memories of Oswego as a child (1906 - 1916).
Harriette Laudise writes concerning a donation of copies of newspaper clippings about Emily Howland.
Phebe M. King writes concerning publications and papers by and about Emily Howland.
Margaret Karch Lasky David Nellis
Talk by Dr. Dorothy Rogers. Founders Day. Professor Recognition Ceremony. September 10, 1981. Four typed pages.
Paper by Dr. Dorothy Rogers. "The All-Time Greats". 6 typed pages. n.d. Includes information about Hermann Krusi, Richard K. Piez, Ralph W. Swetman, Caroline L. G. Scales, Isaac B. Poucher, Matilda Cooper Poucher, Amos Farnham, Margaret K. Smith, Henry Straight, Emma Dickinson Straight, Caroline V. Sinnamon, Clara Armstrong, Hideo Takamine, Ellor Carlile Ripley, Mary Sheldon Barnes, and Earl Barnes.
Judy Wellman
Anne C. Edmonds, College Librarian, Mount Holyoke College. Memories/biography of Dr. Radley. July 1983.
(Formerly 1/9/92)

12 black and white photographs. Digital versions of these photos can be found in the Image Management area of this record. Photograph descriptions as follows:
Dr. Radley in academic robes. (Part of 2006.024 Accession.) 5" x 7"
-2 Dr. Radley and 3 unidentified male students at Shady Shore. 5" x 7"
-3 Dr. Virginia L. Radley, far right. 5" x 7"
- 4 Dr. Radley. Head and shoulders, partial profile. 3" x 2". Two photographs.
- 5 Dr. Radley, left, at Shady Shore greeting an unidentified woman. c. 1980's. 5" x 7"
- 6 Foster S. Brown, left, and Dr. Virginia L. Radley in front of Shady Shore. c. 1980's. 8" x 10"
- 7 Dr. Virginia L. Radley at her desk in Culkin Hall. c. 1980's. 5" x 7"
- 8 Dr. Virginia L. Radley. c. 1980's. 5" x 7"
- 9 Dr. Virginia L. Radley, left, in academic robe and mortat board. 5" x 7"
- 10 Dr. Radley at her desk. 1985. From the Undergraduate Catalog, page 3. ( 5" x 7". 2 copies. Third copy is 8" x 4"
- 11 Dr. Virginia L. Radley, right, at podium. Torchlight Ceremony. 1987. Sheldon Statue is in the background. 8" x 10"
- 12 Dr. Radley at podium. c. 1970's. 8" x 10"
(Photos 2 through 12 were formerly with archive # 52/1/192)

Clippings and other published materials relating to Dr. Radley, including the following:
"Highest Ranking Woman in SUNY". The Oswegonian, August 1, 1974.
"Addresses AAUW. Broader Issues of Higher Education Dr. Radley Topic". The Palldium-Times. December 2, 1974.
"Radley defies college stereotype" by Dick Schulman. The Oswegonian. December 21, 1976.
"Radley's Name Not Included On Faculty List". Palladium-Times. March 6, 1978.
Letters to the Editor in response to March 6th article. Palladium-TImes. March 19, 1978.
Press release from the Office of Public Relations concerning the appointment of Dr. Radley as president of SUNY Oswego. March 22, 1978.
"Dr. Radley New SUNY Oswego President". Palladium-Times. March 22, 1978.
"Oswego president. Woman joins SUNY elite". Syracuse Herald-Journal. March 23, 1978.

"Oswego college president a former Nazareth dean". Rochester Democrat and Chronicle. March 30, 1978.
"Krupsak seeks student action". Syracuse Herald-Journal. March 30, 1978.
"Oswego college president a former Nazareth dean" by Kevin Dilworth. Rochester Democrat and Chronicle. March 30, 1978.
"Krupsak Sees 'Overreaction' Possible in Lake Ban". Palladium-Times. March 30, 1978.
"Dr. Radley Moving to Form Adminstrative Team". Palladium-Times. April 24, 1978.
"Adminstrative Team Members Sought by SUCO President". Palladium-Times. May 22, 1978.
"Radley Named to Bank Council". Palladium-Times. May 25, 1978.
Photograph of Dr. Foster S. Brown and Dr. Virginia L. Radley in front of Shady Shore. Syracuse Herald-Journal. October 1978.
"The Boss at Oswego" by Richard G. Case. Empire magazine, The Syracuse Herald-American. August 27, 1978.
"Iron Fist in a Velvet Glove. SUNY Oswego's new president, Virginia Radley, has definite ideas about how a college should be run". Syracuse Alumni Quarterly, Fall 1978. 3 copies
"Inauguration of Radley to highlight Alumni weekend". Oswegonian, September 28, 1978.
"Medal of Office Designed For Radley Innauguration". Palladium-Times, October 5, 1978.
"President's Colloquia Features Inaugural Program". Palladium-Times, October 6, 1978.
"Dr. Radley Inaugurated as President at SUNY Oswego". Includes photograph. The Palladium-Times. October 7, 1978.
"College president inauguration. Radley takes reins". Syracuse Herald-American. October 8, 1978.
"Dr. Radley Assumes Presidency at SUCO". Palladium-Times, October 9, 1978. Includes 4 photographs with captions.
"Virginia Radley: Ready When the Opportunity Came". November 15, 1978.
"Women Have Played Role in Development of SUCO". Palladium-Times, December 4, 1978.
"Woman Heads SUNY College". Palladium-Times. January 31, 1979.
"Dr. Radley Honored By Legislature". March 12, 1979.
"Legislature commends President Radley". April 1979. The SUNY News.
"College President Declares Hiring Moratorium. Budget Sparks Action". Palladium-Times, November 9, 1979.
"Now on Sentry Board - Dr. Radley In Demand". Palladium-Times, November 29, 1979

Newspaper clippings and other published materials relating to Dr. Radley.
"Demonstrating Role Model". February 18, 1980. Syracuse Post-Standard.
"Radley Muzzling Council?" Palladium-Times, February 21, 1980.
"Research Pact Signed Here". Photograph and caption, "Officials at SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry and SUNY Oswego sign cooperative programming pact to increase inter-campus cooperation in research, public service and educational programs in the natural and environmental sciences. Seated (from left) are Dr. Ralph Spencer, Oswego provost; Dr. Edward Palmer, ESF president; Dr. Virginia Radley, Oswego president; and Dr. Donald Behrend, ESF vice president for program affairs. Standing (from left) are ESF and Oswego officials including Dr. Ronald Scrudato, Dr. James Geis, Dr. Robert Gubbi Sachidanandan, Dr. Kathryn Martin, and Dr. John Gannon". Palladium-Times, April 25, 1980.
"Overview of women in higher education" by Dorothy Austin. Milwaukee Sentinel. April 29, 1980.
"Women in Higher Education: Past, Present, Future. Highlights of Wingspread Conference, April 28 - 29, 1980". Comment. June, 1980.
"So You Want to Be a College President" by Lee Hall. The Chronicle. July 21, 1980. Page 48.
"SUCO Union Attacks Radley". Oswego Valley News, December 23, 1980.
"Low Morale at SUCO". Oswego Valley News, March 10, 1981.
"Women Presidents Make the Grade at Area Colleges". Includes article on Dr. Radley and Patti McGill Peterson. The Post-Standard. November 3, 1981.
"SUCO President Explains Firing Procedure". The Post-Standard. November 24, 1981.

Newspaper clippings and other published materials relating to Dr. Radley.
"Women's World 1982. 19th Century Scholar Is 20th Century Woman". Palladium-Times. January 11, 1982.
"Contract Signing -- Peg Hamilton (front row far right) watches as Dr. Virginia Radley puts her signature on a one-year pact that will allow the Senior Citizens Nutrition Program to move to the Swetman Hall cafetorium effective Monday. Also on hand for the signing Wednesday morning were Oswego County Opportunities Executive Director Peter Geiter (front row, far left) and college administrators Dr. Willard Schum (top right) and Bernie Henderson (top left). . . " Palladium-Times, February 27, 1982.
"Despite rumors, Radley's staying". Oswegonian News. March 11, 1982.
"SUCO President to Give Talk at Salvation Army". Oswego County Messenger, March 11, 1982.
"SUCO President To Address Reps On Budget Impact". Oswego County Messenger, March 12, 1982.
"Dr. Radley In Washington: Aid Cuts Foreshadow Problems". Palladium-Times, March 16, 1982.
"D'Amato Calms Fears Of College Presidents". March 18, 1982.
"SUCO President Deplores 'Pot Shots' ". Oswego County Messenger, March 29, 1982.
"There is danger in ignorance concerning 'Gulliver' ". Dr. Donald Vanouse. Oswegonian. April 22, 1982.
"Freedom, Responsibility Go Hand in Hand" by Dr. Virginia Radley. Palladium-Times. May 12, 1982.
"Radley forum" by Andy Leahy. Oswegonian News. May 13, 1982.
"Two Oswego County Women To be Honored". Oswego County Messenger, September 9, 1982.
"Radley Speaks Out On Education". Palladium-Times, September 15, 1982. "Educator Honored - Dr. Virginia Radley . . . is presented with the 'Trailblazer in Education' award by Dr. Helena Bain Howe on behalf of the Central New York chapter, National Organization of Women". Oswego Valley News, October 28, 1982.
"9 Unsung Heroines to Be Honored. The Oswego County Messenger. September 27, 1982.
"Chamber of Commerce Honors Dr. Radley" by Antone Clark. Palladium-Times. December 1, 1982.
"Women's rating guide gives Syracuse University just 1 star" by Hart Seely. Herald-Journal Metro. December 1, 1982.
"Chamber of Commerce Honors Dr. Radley". Palladium-Times, December 1, 1982.
"Radley looks ahead to college's future plans" by Patricia Culligan. Oswegonian. December 2, 1982.
"Radley: SUNY in Trouble" by Antone Clark. The Palladium-Times. December 2, 1982.
"Oswego State Scores Well in Women's Guide to Colleges". The Post-Standard. December 3, 1982.
"An Impressive Public Figure". Palladium-Times. December 3, 1982.
"Radley comments on Oswego as an institution" by Patricia Culligan. Oswegonian News. December 9, 1982.

"The Business Behind The School". Palladium-Times, January 11, 1983.
"SUCO Faculty Weighs Strategies to Fight Cuts" by Mike Grogan. Post-Standard. February 11, 1983.

"Women-only schools serve purpose: college heads" by Mark D. Frank. Syracuse Herald American. October 9, 1983.
"Two College Presidents Champion Women's Schools" by Mark D. Frank. Buffalo Evening News. October 28, 1983.

did.unittitle: Proposal for a Competency-Based Teacher Education Program

scopecontent.p:
Proposal for a Competency-Based Teacher Education Program leading to the Degree, Master of Science in Education, Major in Industrial Arts and Technology by State University of New York, College of Arts and Sciences at Oswego. 41 pages included appendix and supporting correpondence.
(Formerly 1/9/194)

The US Undergrad, Vol. 1, No. 1, Fall 1984. The Newsletter of the Undergraduate Alumni Association, SUNY Oswego. Front page article includes Perspective from President of College - Dr. Virginia Radley. 2 copies.
125th Commencement, Class of 1986.

Memorandum of Understanding between The State Universty of New York, College of Environmental Science and Forestry and The State University of New York at Oswego signed by Dr. Virginia L. Radley and Edward E. Palmer.
SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry and SUNY Oswego signed cooperative programming pact to increase inter-campus cooperation in research, public service and educational programs in the natural and environmental sciences. See folder 02-02 for newspaper photograph and caption. 1 page.
Memorial Service signature book. Ringed binder. Also included memorial service invitation (2 copies). Five pages of signatures.

Dr. Radley's appointment book includes handwrittten notes, receipts (from hotels, restaurants, stores), and vouchers (loose and stapled).
Black cover, spiral-bound.

Dr. Radley's appointment book includes handwritten notes, lists, receipts (loose and stapled) and vouchers reflecting her travels, meetings, and lectures.
Black cover, sprial-bound.

Includes handwritten notes and a few loose notes and miscellaneous papers. Also included is Dr. Radley's business card while Executive Vice President - Provost.
Black cover, sprial-bound.

The appointment book is very full of handwritten notes, business receipts, vouchers, and statements reflect Dr. Radley's travels, lectures and professional life.
Many loose papers. Handle with care and concern for original order. Black cover, sprial-bound.

Appointment book contains handwritten notes, a few loose notes, official college calendar, Board of Trustees schedule of meetings, College Council schedule of meetings and miscellaneous papers relating to SUNY Oswego.
Black cover, spiral-bound.

These papers relate to the loose and stapled papers in Dr. Radley's appointment books, including 1976 European trip receipts from restaurants and hotels. Also includes 1976 correspondence, and1979 application for license in the citizens radio service. Spiral notebook has handwritten label, " Dr. V. L. Radley 1976 spring to summer log. Florence, Italy, Belgium, SUNY study programs ". Handwritten notes.

did.unittitle: SUNY College at Oswego: Its Second Century Unfolds

scopecontent.p: "SUNY College at Oswego: Its Second Century Unfolds"by Dorothy Rogers. 1988. Signed bookplate from Virginia L. Radley, former president of SUCO and member of the Edward Austin Sheldon Society.

Plaque has the following information:
" College at Oswego. State University of New York. Let Each Become All He Is Capable Of Being. 1948 1861 "
The plaque is mounted to a green felt covered board and framed. Below the plaque is a brass label, " President Virginia Radley ".

did.unittitle: Framed portrait of Dr. Virginia Radley

scopecontent.p:
Framed portrait of Dr. Virginia Radley. Gold frame 21" x 17". Linen matt with gold trim. Linen is soiled. Black & white photograph. 14" x 10.5"
The framed portrait was transferred to the college archives from University Development after being removed from Sheldon Hall.
